rounds.name: Online Assessment
points: 2-3 frontend coding problems focusing on DOM manipulation and algorithms
Common topics: arrays, strings, basic recursion, and object manipulation
May include MCQs on HTML, CSS, JavaScript fundamentals
Time management is key - aim to complete all problems

rounds.name: Machine Coding Round
points: Build a complete UI component from scratch (e.g., autocomplete, infinite scroll, image carousel)
Focus on clean code, component structure, and vanilla JS or React
Demonstrate responsive design and cross-browser compatibility
Working functionality matters more than pixel-perfect design

rounds.name: Technical Interview (DSA)
points: 1-2 easy-to-medium DSA problems with live coding
Focus on arrays, strings, hash maps, and basic tree traversal
Explain your approach and discuss time/space complexity
May include JavaScript-specific questions (closures, promises, event loop)

rounds.name: Technical Interview (Frontend)
points: Deep dive into React concepts: hooks, state management, component lifecycle
Questions on CSS (Flexbox, Grid, responsive design techniques)
Browser fundamentals: event bubbling, rendering process, performance
Build a small component live and explain your design choices

rounds.name: Hiring Manager / Cultural Fit
points: Discussion about past projects and your role in them
Behavioral questions on teamwork, learning, and handling feedback
Why this company and role? Show genuine interest
Ask thoughtful questions about team structure and growth opportunities

easy: Keep practicing DSA regularly to stay sharp
Network and seek referrals to improve chances
doable: DSA fundamentals are essential - solve 75+ problems
Master React and modern frontend tooling
Prepare for machine coding rounds with timed practice
challenging: Strong DSA is mandatory - aim for 120+ problems
Deep understanding of React internals and optimization
Referrals significantly improve your chances - start networking
stretch: This requires 6-8 months of focused preparation
DSA mastery is non-negotiable at this level
Consider building more experience before targeting unicorns

rounds.name: Online Assessment
points: 3-4 coding problems ranging from easy to medium difficulty
Focus on JavaScript problem-solving and algorithmic thinking
May include frontend-specific challenges (DOM manipulation, async operations)
Passing score typically 60-70% to proceed to interviews

rounds.name: DSA Round 1
points: 1-2 medium problems on arrays, strings, or hash maps
Expected to arrive at optimal solution with hints
Code on shared editors like CoderPad or HackerRank
Interviewer evaluates problem-solving approach and communication

rounds.name: DSA Round 2 / Frontend Fundamentals
points: Could be another DSA round or deep dive into JavaScript internals
Topics: closures, prototypes, event loop, promises, this keyword
Questions on React: virtual DOM, reconciliation, hooks, performance
Write code to demonstrate concepts (e.g., implement Promise.all)

rounds.name: Machine Coding / UI Round
points: Build a real-world component: search with autocomplete, pagination, filters
Use React or vanilla JavaScript based on company preference
Focus on code organization, reusability, and edge case handling
Bonus points for responsive design and accessibility considerations

rounds.name: Hiring Manager / Bar Raiser
points: Behavioral questions using STAR format (Situation, Task, Action, Result)
Deep dive into your best project - technical decisions and trade-offs
Questions about handling challenges, tight deadlines, and collaboration
Culture fit assessment - research company values beforehand

easy: Focus on HTML, CSS, and JavaScript fundamentals
Practice basic coding problems for aptitude tests
Prepare clear explanations of your projects
doable: Strengthen your core frontend skills - HTML, CSS, JS
Learn React basics and build simple applications
Practice common interview questions and coding basics
challenging: Solid understanding of web fundamentals is essential
Build a few portfolio projects to showcase
Focus on communication and explaining concepts clearly
stretch: Focus on fundamentals over advanced concepts
This should be very achievable with basic preparation

rounds.name: Aptitude & Online Test
points: Quantitative aptitude, logical reasoning, and verbal ability
1-2 easy coding problems (basic loops, conditionals, arrays)
MCQs on HTML, CSS, JavaScript basics
Focus on accuracy over speed - cutoff-based filtering

rounds.name: Technical Interview 1
points: Questions on HTML tags, CSS selectors, and JavaScript syntax
Explain concepts: var vs let vs const, event delegation, box model
Simple coding: reverse a string, find duplicates in array
Project discussion - be ready to explain your contributions clearly

rounds.name: Technical Interview 2
points: Deeper dive into JavaScript: closures, hoisting, callbacks
Basic React questions if it's on your resume: JSX, props, state
May ask to build a simple layout or debug existing code
Focus on fundamentals - breadth over depth

rounds.name: HR Interview
points: Standard questions: strengths, weaknesses, why this company
Career goals and willingness to learn new technologies
Salary expectations (be realistic for fresher roles)
Relocation flexibility and notice period discussion

easy: Maintain strong DSA practice - solve problems regularly
Prepare for frontend system design discussions

doable: DSA is the primary filter - solve 150+ LeetCode problems
Master React, performance optimization, and web fundamentals

challenging: DSA mastery is mandatory - aim for 200+ problems (medium/hard)

rounds.name: Recruiter Screen
points: Initial call to verify your background and interest
Overview of the interview process and timeline
Questions about visa status, location preferences, start date
Opportunity to ask about the team and role expectations

rounds.name: Phone/Online Technical Screen
points: 1-2 coding problems on shared editor (CoderPad, Google Docs)
Medium difficulty - arrays, strings, hash maps, or trees
Focus on clean code, edge cases, and optimal time complexity
Strong communication is essential - think out loud throughout

rounds.name: Onsite: Coding Round 1
points: Medium to hard DSA problem with live whiteboard or code editor
Common topics: dynamic programming, trees, graphs, recursion
Interviewer evaluates problem breakdown and optimization
Expect follow-up questions to extend or modify your solution

rounds.name: Onsite: Coding Round 2
points: Another DSA problem, potentially harder or different domain
May involve advanced data structures or complex logic
Write clean, bug-free code under time pressure
Discuss multiple approaches before settling on implementation

rounds.name: Onsite: Frontend System Design
points: Design a frontend system: autocomplete, infinite scroll, feed
Cover component architecture, state management, API design
Discuss performance: lazy loading, code splitting, caching
Address accessibility, error handling, and edge cases

rounds.name: Onsite: Behavioral / Googleyness
points: Amazon: Leadership Principles with STAR format
Google: Googleyness - collaboration, growth mindset, adaptability
Prepare stories about ownership, conflict, learning from failure
Questions like 'Tell me about a time you had to learn something new quickly'

rounds.name: Hiring Committee & Team Match
points: Google: Packet reviewed by hiring committee for final decision
Amazon: Bar raiser provides independent assessment
Team matching calls to find mutual fit
Process can take 2-4 weeks post-onsite

projects.title: Interactive Todo List with React
projects.description: Build a fully functional todo app with React hooks, local storage persistence, and filter/search functionality
projects.shortDescription: React todo app with CRUD operations and persistence
projects.fullDescription: Create a production-quality todo application using React hooks for state management, localStorage for data persistence, and modern CSS for responsive design. This project teaches component composition, state management, event handling, and local data persistence - all fundamental skills for React development.

implementationSteps.title: Set Up Project Structure
implementationSteps.description: Initialize a React project using Vite or Create React App. Set up component folder structure: App.jsx (main container), TodoList (renders todos), TodoItem (individual todo), AddTodoForm (input form). Create basic styling with CSS modules or Tailwind CSS for a clean, responsive UI.

implementationSteps.title: Implement State Management with Hooks
implementationSteps.description: Use useState to manage the todos array and current input. Each todo should be an object with id, text, completed, and createdAt properties. Implement functions: addTodo(), toggleTodo(), deleteTodo(), and editTodo(). Use useEffect to sync todos with localStorage on every state change.

implementationSteps.title: Build Add & Display Functionality
implementationSteps.description: Create the AddTodoForm component with a controlled input field. Validate that todo text is not empty before adding. Display the todo list using TodoList and TodoItem components. Pass todos and action handlers (toggle, delete) as props. Use unique IDs (Date.now() or uuid library) for each todo.

implementationSteps.title: Add Filters and Search
implementationSteps.description: Implement filter buttons: All, Active, Completed. Use a filter state to track the current view and conditionally render filtered todos. Add a search input that filters todos by text content in real-time. Combine filter and search logic for powerful todo management.

implementationSteps.title: Polish & Deploy
implementationSteps.description: Add animations for todo add/remove using CSS transitions or Framer Motion. Implement edit mode for todos (double-click to edit). Add a 'Clear Completed' button. Ensure responsive design for mobile devices. Deploy to Vercel or Netlify with a custom domain, and add the live link to your portfolio.

projects.title: Live Weather Dashboard
projects.description: Create a weather app fetching real-time data from OpenWeather API with location search, 5-day forecast, and dynamic backgrounds
projects.shortDescription: Weather app with API integration and geolocation
projects.fullDescription: Build a modern weather dashboard that fetches live weather data from the OpenWeather API. Implement location-based weather using browser geolocation, search functionality for any city, 5-day forecast display, and dynamic UI that changes based on weather conditions. This project demonstrates API integration, async JavaScript, error handling, and creating a polished user experience.

implementationSteps.title: API Setup & Data Fetching
implementationSteps.description: Sign up for a free OpenWeather API key. Create a weather service module that handles API calls: getCurrentWeather(city) and getForecast(city). Use async/await with try-catch for error handling. Parse the JSON response and extract relevant data: temperature, description, humidity, wind speed, and forecast array.

implementationSteps.title: Build Current Weather Display
implementationSteps.description: Create a CurrentWeather component that displays city name, current temperature, weather description, and icon. Use the OpenWeather icon codes to display weather icons. Add additional details: feels like, humidity, wind speed, pressure. Implement a loading spinner while data is being fetched.

implementationSteps.title: Implement Search & Geolocation
implementationSteps.description: Add a search bar component with autocomplete suggestions (optional). On search submit, fetch weather for the entered city. Implement geolocation: use navigator.geolocation to get user's coordinates, then convert to city using reverse geocoding API. Handle permission denied and geolocation errors gracefully.

implementationSteps.title: Add 5-Day Forecast Display
implementationSteps.description: Create a Forecast component that displays the 5-day forecast in a horizontal scrollable card layout. For each day, show: date, high/low temperature, weather icon, and description. Filter the 3-hour interval data to get one forecast per day (e.g., noon forecast). Make the forecast responsive with grid or flexbox.

implementationSteps.title: Dynamic Themes & Polish
implementationSteps.description: Change the app background based on weather conditions: sunny (blue gradient), rainy (grey), cloudy (light grey), night (dark blue). Add smooth transitions between theme changes. Implement temperature unit toggle (°C / °F). Add error messages for invalid cities or API failures. Deploy to Vercel with environment variables for API key security.

projects.title: E-Commerce Product Page
projects.description: Build a full-featured product page with image gallery, cart functionality, size/color selection, and checkout flow
projects.shortDescription: Product page with cart, variants, and responsive design
projects.fullDescription: Create a production-quality e-commerce product page featuring an interactive image gallery with zoom, product variant selection (size, color), add-to-cart functionality with a cart sidebar, quantity controls, and a multi-step checkout form. This advanced project showcases complex state management, form handling, validation, and creating an excellent user experience with animations and responsive design.

implementationSteps.title: Design Product Data Model
implementationSteps.description: Create a product object structure with: id, name, price, images array, sizes, colors, description, reviews. Design cart item structure: product details, selectedSize, selectedColor, quantity. Set up context or Redux for global cart state management. Plan components: ProductGallery, ProductInfo, VariantSelector, AddToCart, Cart, CheckoutForm.

implementationSteps.title: Build Image Gallery with Zoom
implementationSteps.description: Create an image gallery with thumbnails and main image display. Implement click-to-enlarge functionality using a lightbox modal. Add left/right navigation arrows to cycle through images. Use CSS transforms for smooth image transitions. On mobile, make the gallery swipeable with touch gestures (react-swipeable library).

implementationSteps.title: Implement Variant Selection & Cart
implementationSteps.description: Build size and color selectors with visual feedback (highlight selected option). Validate that both size and color are selected before allowing add-to-cart. On 'Add to Cart' click, update cart context with selected product details. Create a cart sidebar that slides in from right, showing cart items with thumbnails, quantity controls, subtotal. Add 'Remove' buttons for cart items.

implementationSteps.title: Build Quantity Controls & Cart Logic
implementationSteps.description: Implement increment/decrement buttons for cart quantities with min (1) and max (stock) validation. Calculate cart subtotal, taxes, and total dynamically. Handle edge cases: adding the same product with different variants creates separate cart items. Persist cart to localStorage so it survives page refreshes. Add a 'Clear Cart' button with confirmation.

implementationSteps.title: Create Checkout Form with Validation
implementationSteps.description: Build a multi-step checkout: (1) Shipping Address, (2) Payment Method, (3) Order Review. Use controlled components for all form inputs. Implement validation: email format, required fields, phone number pattern, zip code format. Show inline error messages below each field. Display order summary sidebar with cart items and total. On final submit, show a success message with order confirmation.

implementationSteps.title: Polish, Accessibility & Deploy
implementationSteps.description: Add smooth animations for cart slide-in, variant selection, and page transitions using Framer Motion. Ensure keyboard navigation works for all interactive elements. Add ARIA labels for screen readers. Implement responsive design: mobile-first approach with breakpoints for tablet and desktop. Optimize images with lazy loading. Deploy to Vercel/Netlify and add to your portfolio with screenshots and feature highlights.
